instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: Found U8080 to be shorted on this 3437. Changed it, and now on pin 7 (P5VS0_FET_RAMP) its reading 2.45v... is this typical of this circuit? It looks like there is cap 8081 in line, but this reading seems off. Any insight? (Liquid damaged board) This board isnt powering on, and I am in the process of diagnosis.

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: need the basics. do you have a green/red light on the charger? you should be getting 5v on pin 5 but only if you are getting 5v on pin 1 and 2 of u8080. what pin was shorted to ground on u8080?

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: Enable to U8080 is more of interest. First need PPBUS and S5 stuff to be present.

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message:
Yes green light on charger, 0 at pin 5
3.3 at the EN pin
I think it was an internal short as the component got hot as hell and burned me.

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: So is 5V on both sides of U8080, if so it is working fine.

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: I have voltage on pins 1, 2, 3 but no voltage at 6 or 7. Same scenario, I change it out, and it gets broiling hot. checked the legs, and no short to ground. I highly doubt its the actual component as I have tried a couple different ones.

threads.title: 820-3437 u8080
threads.message: Something is drawing too much current through U8080. Inject voltage on 5V_S0 and see what heats up.
